data.title: The Last Starship (2017)
data.meta_description: Conflict and tension looms heavily across the broken remains of a distant, post-apocalyptic world. Controlled by a race of oppressive genetically-enhanced humans, the last natural-born humans have no choice but to bow down to their rule. The only alternative is to wander the vast wastelands surrounding the last habitable city, whilst relentlessly hunted by roaming pack of mutated monsters. Meanwhile, outside the towering walls of the citadel, aboard a massive hulking army tank, an uprising occurs amongst the natural-born crew. Their hope lies in the legend of the Republic of EZO: said to return aboard the last starship....
data.text:
This movie is bad but it's not without it's good stuff. When you start it, you seem to understand what's going on and kinda like the movie but then they really get into the story. It's a lot of shit going on in this movie. It's like three races around the world or another planet. I don't know. They never say where the hell they are. So you just assume it's earth. On this other earth or whatever it is, is like three different factions, a race of giant aliens, some killers robots and a race of zombies. Thinking back on the movie now it's kinda like command and conquer but extreme. All this sounds kinda cool, but it's just…

I liked the way they used the cheap cgi to their advantage and created a kind of steam punk world where the bad cgi fit in perfectly. They really tried to set up an epic here complete with many races, factions and bad guys. The way they went in and out of German and English gave it an advanced civilization feel and the heavy Japanese influence, hinting it to be the current controlling power, is a different choice than we usually see in these future world movies and I liked it. Huxley's name is used throughout as a sort of explicative which is fitting. There's some cool ideas here and a fair attempt at a massive world build but ultimately…
